Very cool video, however using conservation of rotational energy is incorrect in this explanation because rotational energy is not conserved.  It is converted into heat by the brake initially and it is added to the system by the engine towards the end. Rotational kinetic energy is also a scalar and can't be used to describe directions of rotation.  Descriptions involving torque and conservation of angular momentum are the correct ways to analyze the changes in rotation in the video.

It's a reaction force with the centre of inertia at the axle of the rear wheel and the opposing force at the moment of inertia at the brake caliper. This sets torque into the swing arm which in turn torques the front wheel down. Smarter today - but tomorrow is a new day...!

Why would rotational energy matter.  Rotational energy isn't conserved.  Only energy.  Energy was lost from the system in the form of heat from using the breaks.  The bike did gain angular energy from the wheel but not as much as you think because angular energy is  I*w^2 and angular momentum is I*w it is impossible for both to be conserved at the same time if w is different in the two bodies. @SmarterEveryDay

Essentially, yes. When you apply the brake and stop the wheel, all of the angular momentum is transferred into torque which will pitch the bike. Conversely, if the tire is stopped initially and then you apply a torque which is converted to angular momentum, then the bike will pitch in the opposite direction.

Whats more is that if you grab the front brake while in the air, not only will the front tire drop due to the same torque that the rear wheel would experience but it will also track to the left due the change in gyro forces on it. This effect is minimized when considering the rear tire because there is more weight over the rear of the bike, and acceleration = force/mass.

Right. So you have angular momentum conserved in the wheel. As the back brake is tapped, the wheel goes locks up and can be imagined as forming one particle along with the chassis. That angular momentum is still conserved, but is being distributed across the entire chassis, thus giving the entire bike angular momentum in the same direction as the wheel

To answer the question you posed in the video, explaining why counter-spin is generated by using the throttle is actually quite simple.  To alter the pitch, he uses the rotational energy by using the brake.  The inverse of this effect is created when he uses the throttle, because the rotational energy is transferred from the bike back to the wheel.

I think angular momentum (as you have already described in the intro) is the best way forward. The equations are simple and you can make accurate predictions as to by what degree the bike will rotate when the brake is applied (knowing initial conditions of course). 
Rotational energy obviously plays an important part, but as alex mentioned, it runs around anywhere (mostly heat, may be sound and a few other things). It would be difficult to make any predictions using that.

The brake is only converting mechanical energy into heat so long as things are moving and sliding against one another.  Without the resistance that comes from the tire in contact with the ground, there is almost no sliding between the brake pads and disks.  The losses to friction and heat in this case are completely negligible.

@MrRoyalestCrown Not entirely accurate.  These principles would still be in effect even in a vacuum.  

The reason the bike will pitch down is because of the momentum of the wheels.  Both wheels have rotational velocity (rotational momentum) when he leaves the ramp.  Now, if you slam on the front brake and that momentum doesn't just disappear, it transfers into something else.  In this case it's transferring into the fork of the bike.

Newton's Third Law. As the wheel spins faster, it tilts the bike's nose up because the rotation of the wheel increasing the air pressure on top of the wheel, forcing the back wheel down. When he revs it up the bike pitches up because of opposite and equal reaction (newton's thrid law). Normally the ground and friction would be there to keep the bike level, but in the air (without friction) the opposite force of the wheel spinning goes through the whole frame and pitches the bike down. While the bike is in the air we can treat it as an isolated system (apart from gravity, which exerts no torque). When he revs the throttle, the bike puts angular momentum in the back wheel. In order to do this the bike itself has to receive the same angular momentum in the opposite direction, due to conservation of angular momentum, causing the bike to pitch backwards.

@gsiotas1 Him bending towards the front wheel would affect the rotation a bit, but only a tiny bit (by shifting the weight away from the center of rotation he's changing the I of the formula). If you look the slow motion part more carefully you'll see that he actually slides a bit backwards while rotating (perhaps so he doesn't rotate too much), while the forward rotation accelerates (at a more significant rate) just at the exact moment the wheel stops rotating.
